intro: Faroa axillaris, commonly known as the coastal hibiscus, is a flowering plant native to the coastal regions of southern Africa. It is a shrub that typically grows in sandy or rocky soils along the shoreline. The plant produces showy, trumpet-shaped flowers that are usually pink or red in color. It has palmate leaves with five to seven lobes, and its stems are often covered in fine hairs. Faroa axillaris is adapted to withstand salt spray and strong coastal winds, making it a hardy species found in maritime environments.
